Take-home Exercise 1: Geospatial Analytics for Social Good

Geospatial Analytics for Social Good

Setting the Scene

Water is an important resource to mankind. Clean and accessible water is critical to human health. It provides a healthy environment, a sustainable economy, reduces poverty and ensures peace and security. Yet over 40% of the global population does not have access to sufficient clean water. By 2025, 1.8 billion people will be living in countries or regions with absolute water scarcity, according to UN-Water. The lack of water poses a major threat to several sectors, including food security. Agriculture uses about 70% of the world’s accessible freshwater.

Developing countries are most affected by water shortages and poor water quality. Up to 80% of illnesses in the developing world are linked to inadequate water and sanitation. Despite technological advancement, providing clean water to the rural community is still a major development issues in many countries globally, especially countries in the Africa continent.

To address the issue of providing clean and sustainable water supply to the rural community, a global Water Point Data Exchange (WPdx) project has been initiated. The main aim of this initiative is to collect water point related data from rural areas at the water point or small water scheme level and share the data via WPdx Data Repository, a cloud-based data library. What is so special of this project is that data are collected based on WPDx Data Standard.

Objectives

Geospatial analytics hold tremendous potential to address complex problems facing society. In this study, I will be applying appropriate global and local measures of spatial Association techniques to reveal the spatial patterns of Not Functional water points. For the purpose of this study, Nigeria will be used as the study country.

Setting the Analytical Tools

Before we get started, we need to ensure that spdep, sf, tmap and tidyverse packages of R are currently installed in R.

  • sf is use for importing and handling geospatial data in R,

  • tidyverseis mainly use for wrangling attribute data in R,

  • spdep will be used to compute spatial weights, global and local spatial autocorrelation statistics, and

  • tmap will be used to prepare cartographic quality chropleth map

  • funModeling will be used for rapid Exploratory Data Analysis.

pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse, tmap, spdep, funModeling)

Importing Geospatial Data

In this in-class data, 2 data sets will be used, they are:

  • geo_export: Aspatial WPdx+ data setfrom WPdx Global Data Repositories will be used.

  • nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417: Geospatial data from The Humanitarian Data Exchange portal will be used for Nigeria Level-2 Administrative Boundary (also known as Local Government Area) polygon features GIS data.

First, we are going to import the water point geospatial data (i.e. geo_export) by using the code chunk below.

wp <- st_read(dsn = "data/aspatial", 
             layer = "geo_export",
             crs = 4326)%>%
  
  filter(clean_coun == "Nigeria")

  • st_read() of sf package is used to import geo_export shapefile into R environment and save the imported geospatial data into simple feature data table.

  • filter() of dplyr package is used to extract water point records of Nigeria.

Importing water point geospatial data

Next, write_rds() of readr package is used to save the extracted sf data table (i.e. wp) into an output file in rds data format. The output file is called nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417.rds and it is saved in geospatial sub-folder.

wp_nga <- write_rds(wp,"data/geospatial/nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417.rds")

Importing Nigeria LGA boundary data

Now, we are going to import the LGA boundary data into R environment by using the code chunk below.

nga <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial",
               layer = "nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417",
               crs = 4326)

  • st_read() of sf package is used to import nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417 shapefile into R environment and save the imported geospatial data into simple feature data table.

Data Wrangling

Data Wrangling is the practice of correcting/deleting inaccurate, damaged, improperly formatted, duplicate, or incomplete data from a dataset. I willl now proceed to ensure the data is cleaned before conducting analysis.

Recoding NA values into string

In the code chunk below, replace_na() is used to recode all the NA values in status_cle field into Unknown.

wp_nga <- read_rds("data/geospatial/nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417.rds") %>%
  mutate(status_cle = replace_na(status_cle, "Unknown"))
  • read_rds() is used to read nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417.rds so we can then mutate() to replace the NA values with ‘unknown’.

st_geometry()

The column in the sf data.frame that contains the geometries is a list, of class sfc. We can retrieve the geometry list-column for the waterpoint data.

st_geometry(wp_nga)

The print only displays basic information of the feature class such as type of geometry, the geographic extent of the features and the coordinate system of the data.

glimpse()

Beside the basic feature information, the code chunk below will use glimpse() of dplyr to learn more about the associated attribute information in the data frame.

glimpse(wp_nga)

plot(wp_nga)

Exploratory Data Analysis

In the code chunk below, freq() of funModeling package is used to display the distribution of status_cle field in wp_nga.

freq(data=wp_nga, 
     input = 'status_cle')

From the chart above, we can see that only 48% of waterpoints are functional while 31% is not functional. Thus, we can further our analysis by looking at the types of functional water points and non-functional water points respectively in this next section.

Extracting Water Point Data

In this section, we will extract the water point records by using classes in status_cle field.

Extracting functional water point

In the code chunk below, filter() of dplyr is used to select functional water points.

wpt_functional <- wp_nga %>%
  filter(status_cle %in%
           c("Functional", 
             "Functional but not in use",
             "Functional but needs repair"))
freq(data=wpt_functional, 
     input = 'status_cle')

For functional water points, almost 88% are functional, while 9% requires repair and 3% are not in use. Recommendation could include getting repairs done and operating those not in use, especially in areas where functional waterpoints are few or none currently.

Extracting non-functional water point

In the code chunk below, filter() of dplyr is used to select non-functional water points.

wpt_nonfunctional <- wp_nga %>%
  filter(status_cle %in%
           c("Abandoned/Decommissioned", 
             "Abandoned",
             "Non-Functional",
             "Non functional due to dry season",
             "Non-Functional due to dry season"))
freq(data=wpt_nonfunctional, 
     input = 'status_cle')

Out of those that are non-functional, almost 7.5% are non-functional due to dry season while 1.3% are abandoned/ decommissioned. Thus, the local government can look to tapping on them during wetter seasons or recommission them respectively. However, there are 91.25% non-functional ones which may require further research into the root causes.

Extracting water point with Unknown class

In the code chunk below, filter() of dplyr is used to select water points with unknown status.

wpt_unknown <- wp_nga %>%
  filter(status_cle == "Unknown")

Performing Point-in-Polygon Count

Take nga_wp data and mutate() it to find total wpt, wpt functional, wpt non-functional and wpt unknown for further analysis:

nga_wp <- nga %>% 
  mutate(`total wpt` = lengths(
    st_intersects(nga, wp_nga))) %>%
  mutate(`wpt functional` = lengths(
    st_intersects(nga, wpt_functional))) %>%
  mutate(`wpt non-functional` = lengths(
    st_intersects(nga, wpt_nonfunctional))) %>%
  mutate(`wpt unknown` = lengths(
    st_intersects(nga, wpt_unknown)))

Working with Projection

Firstly, view the coordinate system of wp using st_crs() of sf package below.

st_crs(wp_nga)

Transforming projection of wp from wgs84 to EPSG code for Nigeria (26391):

Use st_transform() of sf package to reproject wp from one coordinate system to another coordinate system mathemetically.

  wp26391 <- st_transform(wp, 26391)
st_crs(wp26391)

Transforming projection of nga_wp from wgs84 to EPSG code for Nigeria (26391):

Similarly, view the coordinate system of nga_wp using st_crs() of sf package below.

  st_crs(nga_wp)

Then, use st_transform() of sf package to reproject nga_wp from one coordinate system to another coordinate system mathemetically.

  nga_wp26391 <- st_transform(nga_wp, 26391)
st_crs(nga_wp26391)

Geoprocessing with sf package

Point-in-polygon count

Scenario: to find out the number of waterpoints in each LGA (Local government area), we can use the point-in-polygon count method.

The code chunk below first identifies waterpoints inside each LGA using st_intersects(), then uses length() of Base R to calculate the number of waterpoints falling inside each LGA.

nga_wp26391$`Waterpoint Count`<- lengths(st_intersects(nga_wp26391, wp26391))

To check the summary statistics of the newly derived Waterpoint Count field, we can use summary() below:

summary(nga_wp26391$`Waterpoint Count`)

To list the area with the most number of waterpoints, the top_n() of dplyr package is used as shown in the code chunk below.

top_n(nga_wp26391, 1,`Waterpoint Count`)

This shows that Jigawa North-West has the most waterpoints.

We can also explore the density of waterpoints by LGAs.

Firstly, the code chunk below uses st_area() of sf package to derive the area of each LGA.

nga_wp26391$Area <- nga_wp26391 %>%
  st_area()

Next, mutate() of dplyr package is used to compute the density by using the code chunk below.

nga_wp26391 <- nga_wp26391 %>%
  mutate(`Waterpoint Density` = `Waterpoint Count`/Area * 1000000)

Then, use ggplot() to plot out the histogram to look at the density across LGAs.

ggplot(data=nga_wp26391, 
       aes(x= as.numeric(`Waterpoint Density`)))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="black", 
                 fill="light blue") +
  labs(title = "Are waterpoints evenly distributed in Nigeria?",
       subtitle= "There are many areas with 1 waterpoint, on the other hand, \n but there are very few areas with at least 5 or 10 waterpoints.",
      x = "Waterpoint density (per km sq)",
      y = "Frequency")

We can also explore if there is any relationship between the waterpoint density and count in the areas.

ggplot(data=nga_wp26391, 
       aes(y = `Waterpoint Count`, 
           x= as.numeric(`Waterpoint Density`)))+
  geom_point(color="black", 
             fill="light blue") +
  xlim(0, 20) +
  ylim(0, 20) +
  labs(title = "",
      x = "Waterpoint density (per km sq)",
      y = "Waterpoint count")

From the chart, there is no correlation as the waterpoint density is still close to zero for areas with 0 to 20 water points, thus showing inconvenient access to water.

Saving the Analytical Data Table

nga_wp <- nga_wp %>%
  mutate(pct_functional = `wpt functional`/`total wpt`) %>%
  mutate(`pct_non-functional` = `wpt non-functional`/`total wpt`)
  • mutate() of dplyr package is used to derive two fields namely pct_functional and pct_non-functional.

Now, we have the tidy sf data table subsequent analysis. We will save the sf data table into rds format.

write_rds(nga_wp, "data/geospatial/nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417.rds")

Before you end this section, please remember to delete away all the raw data. Notice that the only data file left is nga_wp.rds and it’s file size is around 2.1MB.

Visualising the spatial distribution of water points

We will now plot the choropleth map using tmap .

Firstly, for the count for total wpt, wpt functional, wpt non-functional and wpt unknown across all LGAs:

nga_wp <- read_rds("data/geospatial/nga_admbnda_adm2_osgof_20190417.rds")
total <- qtm(nga_wp, "total wpt")
wp_functional <- qtm(nga_wp, "wpt functional")
wp_nonfunctional <- qtm(nga_wp, "wpt non-functional")
unknown <- qtm(nga_wp, "wpt unknown")

tmap_arrange(total, wp_functional, wp_nonfunctional, unknown, asp=1, ncol=2)

Then, for the Distribution of Functional Waterpoints (pct_functional) and Non-Functional Waterpoints (pct_non-functional) below:

tmap_mode("plot")
fun <- tm_shape(nga_wp)+
  tm_fill("pct_functional", 
          style = "jenks", 
          title = "Non-Functional Waterpoint ratio") +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Distribution of Functional Waterpoint Ratio by LGA",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 0.8,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 0.35,
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar() +
  tm_grid(alpha =0.2) +
  tm_credits("", position = c("left", "bottom"))

nfun <- tm_shape(nga_wp)+
  tm_fill("pct_non-functional", 
          style = "jenks",
          title = "Non-Functional Waterpoint ratio") +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Distribution of Non-Functional Waterpoint Ratio by LGA",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 0.8,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 0.35,
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar() +
  tm_grid(alpha =0.2) +
  tm_credits("", position = c("left", "bottom"))

tmap_arrange (fun, nfun, ncol = 2, asp = 1)

Observations from Choropleth Map

From both maps, we can see that the northen regions have relatively higher percentage of functional water points compared to the southern regions, while the southern regions have relatively higher percentage of non-functional water points.

From the observations, we should then consider whether to focus efforts and resources on fixing the non-functional waterpoints in the southern regions. While we can use tmap_mode(“view”) below to see if those areas with non-functional waterpoints are neighbours of areas with functional waterpoints such that they can tap on those functional waterpoints, we should explore the distance between them to see if this option is possible.

Alternative way to “view” map:

tmap_mode("view")
func <- qtm(nga_wp, 
    fill = "pct_functional")

nfunc <- qtm(nga_wp, 
    fill = "pct_non-functional")

tmap_arrange(func, nfunc, ncol =2, asp =1)

Spatial Weights and Applications

Computing Contiguity Spatial Weights

In this section, we will use poly2nb() of spdep package to compute contiguity weight matrices for the study area.

Computing (Queen) Contiguity Spatial Weights

To compute Queen contiguity weight matrix, we set queen = TRUE.

wm_q <- poly2nb(nga_wp, queen=TRUE)
summary(wm_q)

The summary report above shows that there are 774 area units in Nigeria.

  • The most connect area (“Mokwa”) has 14 neighbours. This area can tap on or share its functional waterpoints with its neighbours.
nga_wp$ADM2_EN[508]
wm_q[[508]] #its 14 neighbours

  • There is 1 area (area 86: “Bakassi”) with no neighbours. This areas would require its own functional waterpoint. This may apply to area 138 (“Chanchaga”) and 560 (“Offa”) who only have 1 neighbour, if they and their neighbours do not have functional waterpoints.
nga_wp$ADM2_EN[86]
wm_q[[86]]

nga_wp$ADM2_EN[138]
wm_q[[138]]
nga_wp$ADM2_EN[560]
wm_q[[560]]

  • Areas have an average of 5 neighbours. Most areas, if they do not have their own functional waterpoints, can tap on 5 other neighbours’ waterpoints.

To see the nearest neighbours of each LGA, we can display the complete weight matrix by using str().

str(wm_q)

Computing (Rook) Contiguity Spatial Weights

To compute Rook contiguity weight matrix, we set queen = FALSE.

wm_r <- poly2nb(nga_wp, queen=FALSE)
summary(wm_r)

This presents results for similar observations to the Queen’s method.

Visualising contiguity weights:

A connectivity graph takes a point and displays a line to each neighboring point. We will need points to associate with each polygon before we can make our connectivity graph. We will calculate these in the sf package before moving onto the graphs.

To get our longitude values we map the st_centroid function over the geometry column of us.bound and access the longitude value through double bracket notation [[]] and 1.

longitude <- map_dbl(nga_wp$geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[1]])

We do the same for latitude with one key difference. We access the second value per each centroid with [[2]].

latitude <- map_dbl(nga_wp$geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[2]])

Now that we have latitude and longitude, we use cbind to put longitude and latitude into the same object.

coords <- cbind(longitude, latitude)

We check the first few observations to see if things are formatted correctly.

head(coords)

We can then plot both Queen and Rook contiguity based neighbours maps with plot().

Plotting Queen contiguity based neighbours map

plot(nga_wp$geometry, border="lightgrey")
plot(wm_q, coords, pch = 19, cex = 0.6, add = TRUE, col= "red")

Plotting Rook contiguity based neighbours map

plot(nga_wp$geometry, border="lightgrey")
plot(wm_r, coords, pch = 19, cex = 0.6, add = TRUE, col= "red")

Computing distance based neighbours

In this section, we can derive distance-based weight matrices by using dnearneigh() of spdep package.

Firstly, determine the cut-off distance, the upper limit for distance band by using the steps below:

  • Return a matrix with the indices of points belonging to the set of the k nearest neighbours of each other by using knearneigh() of spdep.

  • Convert the knn object returned by knearneigh() into a neighbours list of class nb with a list of integer vectors containing neighbour region number ids by using knn2nb().

  • Return the length of neighbour relationship edges by using nbdists() of spdep. The function returns in the units of the coordinates if the coordinates are projected, in km otherwise.

  • Remove the list structure of the returned object by using unlist().

#coords <- coordinates(nga_wp)
k1 <- knn2nb(knearneigh(coords))
k1dists <- unlist(nbdists(k1, coords, longlat = TRUE))
summary(k1dists)

The summary report shows that the largest first nearest neighbour distance is 71.66 km, so using this as the upper threshold gives certainty that all units will have at least one neighbour (excluding those that do not have neighbours).

Then, compute the fixed distance weight matrix by using dnearneigh() as shown in the code chunk below.

wm_d62 <- dnearneigh(coords, 0, 72, longlat = TRUE)
wm_d62

From the results above, we can see that each region has an average of 23 neighbours per region using the distance based weight matrix.

We can use str() to display the content of wm_d62 weight matrix.

str(wm_d62)

The code chunk below then plots the fixed distance weight matrix:

par(mfrow=c(1,2))
plot(nga_wp$geometry, border="lightgrey")
plot(k1, coords, add=TRUE, col="red", length=0.08, main="1st nearest neighbours")
plot(nga_wp$geometry, border="lightgrey")
plot(wm_d62, coords, add=TRUE, pch = 19, cex = 0.6, main="Distance link")

The red lines show the links of 1st nearest neighbours and the black lines show the links of neighbours within the cut-off distance of 72km.

Computing adaptive distance weight matrix

One of the characteristics of fixed distance weight matrix is that more densely settled areas (usually the urban areas) tend to have more neighbours and the less densely settled areas (usually the rural counties) tend to have lesser neighbours. Having many neighbours smoothes the neighbour relationship across more neighbours.

It is possible to control the numbers of neighbours directly using k-nearest neighbours, either accepting asymmetric neighbours or imposing symmetry as shown in the code chunk below. For this analysis, we set the number of neighbours (k) to 10.

knn10 <- knn2nb(knearneigh(coords, k=10))
knn10

Each LGA has 10 neighbours, no less no more! We can display the content of the matrix using str().

str(knn10)

Plotting distance based neighbours

We can plot the weight matrix using the code chunk below.

plot(nga_wp$geometry, border="lightgrey")
plot(knn10, coords, pch = 19, cex = 0.6, add = TRUE, col = "red")

Weights based on IDW

To derive a spatial weight matrix based on Inversed Distance method: First, we will compute the distances between areas by using nbdists( ) of spdep.

dist <- nbdists(wm_q, coords, longlat = TRUE)
ids <- lapply(dist, function(x) 1/(x))
ids

Row-standardised weights matrix

Next, we need to assign weights to each neighboring polygon. In our case, each neighboring polygon will be assigned equal weight (style=“W”). This is accomplished by assigning the fraction 1/(#ofneighbors) to each neighboring county then summing the weighted income values. While this is the most intuitive way to summaries the neighbors’ values it has one drawback in that polygons along the edges of the study area will base their lagged values on fewer polygons thus potentially over- or under-estimating the true nature of the spatial autocorrelation in the data. For this example, we’ll stick with the style=“W” option for simplicity’s sake but note that other more robust options are available, notably style=“B”.

rswm_q <- nb2listw(wm_q, style="W", zero.policy = TRUE)
summary(rswm_q, zero.policy = TRUE)

The zero.policy=TRUE option allows for lists of non-neighbors, since there are regions with no neighbours.

Global Spatial Autocorrelation

Moran’s I test

To see whether the entire area studied are clustered (I > 0), dispersed (I < 0) or random (I is approximately 0), we will have to perform the spatial autocorrelation Moran’s I test on the percentage for both functional and non-functional water points using moran.test() of spdep.

moran.test(nga_wp$`pct_functional`, 
           listw=rswm_q, 
           zero.policy = TRUE, 
           na.action=na.omit)

moran.test(nga_wp$`pct_non-functional`, 
           listw=rswm_q, 
           zero.policy = TRUE, 
           na.action=na.omit)

Interpreting the results

The p value is less than the alpha value of 0.05 for all results above, thus the null hypothesis that the attribute is randomly distributed can be rejected. Given the I > 0, there is spatial clustering with areas with similar percentages of functional and non-functional waterpoints respectively clustering together.

Computing Monte Carlo Moran’s I

The code chunk below performs permutation test for Moran’s I statistic by using moran.mc() of spdep. A total of 1000 simulation will be performed.

set.seed(1234)
func_pct= moran.mc(nga_wp$`pct_functional`, 
                listw=rswm_q, 
                nsim=999, 
                zero.policy = TRUE, 
                na.action=na.omit)
func_pct

set.seed(1234)
nfunc_pct= moran.mc(nga_wp$`pct_non-functional`, 
                listw=rswm_q, 
                nsim=999, 
                zero.policy = TRUE, 
                na.action=na.omit)
nfunc_pct

Visualising Monte Carlo Moran’s I

We should examine the simulated Moran’s I test statistics in greater detail. This can be achieved by plotting the distribution of the statistical values as a histogram by using the code chunk below.

In the code chunk below hist() and abline() of R Graphics are used.

mean(func_pct$res[1:999])
mean(nfunc_pct$res[1:999])

var(func_pct$res[1:999])
var(nfunc_pct$res[1:999])

summary(func_pct$res[1:999])
summary(nfunc_pct$res[1:999])

hist(func_pct$res, 
     freq=TRUE, 
     breaks=20, 
     xlab="Simulated Moran's I")
abline(v=0.5539, 
       col="red") 

hist(nfunc_pct$res, 
     freq=TRUE, 
     breaks=20, 
     xlab="Simulated Moran's I")
abline(v=0.46319, 
       col="red")

Interpreting the Monte Carlo Moran’s I Results

With the histogram distribution and results above with a p-value of less than 0.05, it can be concluded that all the results are statistically significant. The Moran I values (red line) are positive and are on the right of the distribution, thus suggesting both functional and non-functional waterpoints are clustered.

Compute Moran’s I correlogram

MI_corr <- sp.correlogram(wm_q, 
          nga_wp$`wpt non-functional`, 
          order=6, 
          method="I", 
          style="W",
          zero.policy = TRUE)
plot(MI_corr)

print(MI_corr)

Compute Geary’s C correlogram and plot

GC_corr <- sp.correlogram(wm_q, 
                          nga_wp$`wpt non-functional`, 
                          order=6, 
                          method="C", 
                          style="W",
          zero.policy = TRUE)
plot(GC_corr)

print(GC_corr)

Cluster and Outlier Analysis

Local Indicators of Spatial Association or LISA are a collection of geospatial statistical analysis methods for analysing the location related tendency (clusters or outliers) in the attributes of geographically referenced data (points or areas).

Computing local Moran’s I

To compute local Moran’s I, the localmoran() function of spdep will be used. It computes Ii values, given a set of zi values and a listw object providing neighbour weighting information for the polygon associated with the zi values.

fips <- order(nga_wp$ADM1_EN)
localMI <- localmoran(nga_wp$`wpt n-functional`, rswm_q)
head(localMI)

The code chunk below list the content of the local Moran matrix derived by using printCoefmat().

printCoefmat(data.frame(
  localMI[fips,], 
  row.names=nga_wp$ADM1_EN[fips]),
  check.names=FALSE)

Mapping the local Moran’s I

We have to combine the local Moran’s dataframe with the our exisiting Nigeria spatialdataframe before plotting. We will use the cbind() function.

nga_wp.localMI <- cbind(nga_wp,localMI) %>%
  rename(Pr.Ii = Pr.z....E.Ii..)

Using choropleth mapping functions of tmap package, we can plot the local Moran’s I values by using the code chinks below.

tm_shape(nga_wp.localMI) +
  tm_fill(col = "Ii", 
          style = "pretty",
          palette = "RdBu",
          title = "local moran statistics") +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)
localMI.map <- tm_shape(nga_wp.localMI) +
  tm_fill(col = "Ii", 
          style = "pretty", 
          title = "local moran statistics") +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)

pvalue.map <- tm_shape(nga_wp.localMI) +
  tm_fill(col = "Pr.Ii", 
          breaks=c(-Inf, 0.001, 0.01, 0.05, 0.1, Inf),
          palette="-Blues", 
          title = "local Moran's I p-values") +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)

tmap_arrange(localMI.map, pvalue.map, asp=1, ncol=2)

Creating a LISA Cluster Map

The LISA Cluster Map shows the significant locations color coded by type of spatial autocorrelation. The first step before we can generate the LISA cluster map is to plot the Moran scatterplot.

nci <- moran.plot((nga_wp$`pct_non-functional`, rswm_q,
                   labels=as.character(nga_wp$ADM1_EN), 
                   xlab="GDPPC 2012", 
                   ylab="Spatially Lag GDPPC 2012"))

Preparing LISA map classes

The code chunks below show the steps to prepare a LISA cluster map.

quadrant <- vector(mode="numeric",length=nrow(localMI))

Next, derives the spatially lagged variable of interest (i.e. GDPPC) and centers the spatially lagged variable around its mean.

nga_wp$`wpt non-functional` <- lag.listw(rswm_q, nga_wp$`wpt non-functional`)
DV <- nga_wp$`wpt non-functional` - mean(nga_wp$`wpt non-functional`)

This is follow by centering the local Moran’s around the mean.

LM_I <- localMI[,1] - mean(localMI[,1])

Next, we will set a statistical significance level for the local Moran.

signif <- 0.05

These four command lines define the low-low (1), low-high (2), high-low (3) and high-high (4) categories.

quadrant[DV <0 & LM_I>0] <- 1
quadrant[DV >0 & LM_I<0] <- 2
quadrant[DV <0 & LM_I<0] <- 3  
quadrant[DV >0 & LM_I>0] <- 4

Lastly, places non-significant Moran in the category 0.

quadrant[localMI[,5]>signif] <- 0

Plotting LISA map

Now, we can build the LISA map by using the code chunks below.

nga_wp.localMI$quadrant <- quadrant
colors <- c("#ffffff", "#2c7bb6", "#abd9e9", "#fdae61", "#d7191c")
clusters <- c("insignificant", "low-low", "low-high", "high-low", "high-high")

tm_shape(nga_wp.localMI) +
  tm_fill(col = "quadrant", 
          style = "cat", 
          palette = colors[c(sort(unique(quadrant)))+1], 
          labels = clusters[c(sort(unique(quadrant)))+1],
          popup.vars = c("")) +
  tm_view(set.zoom.limits = c(11,17)) +
  tm_borders(alpha=0.5)

Hot Spot and Cold Spot Area Analysis

Beside detecting cluster and outliers, localised spatial statistics can be also used to detect hot spot and/or cold spot areas.

The term ‘hot spot’ has been used generically across disciplines to describe a region or value that is higher relative to its surroundings (Lepers et al 2005, Aben et al 2012, Isobe et al 2015).

Getis and Ord’s G-Statistics

An alternative spatial statistics to detect spatial anomalies is the Getis and Ord’s G-statistics (Getis and Ord, 1972; Ord and Getis, 1995). It looks at neighbours within a defined proximity to identify where either high or low values clutser spatially. Here, statistically significant hot-spots are recognised as areas of high values where other areas within a neighbourhood range also share high values too.

The analysis consists of three steps:

  • Deriving spatial weight matrix

  • Computing Gi statistics

  • Mapping Gi statistics

Deriving distance-based weight matrix

Both distance weight matrix have been derived above:

  • fixed distance weight matrix; and

  • adaptive distance weight matrix.

Deriving the centroid

We will need points to associate with each polygon before we can make our connectivity graph. It will be a little more complicated than just running st_centroid() on the sf object: us.bound. We need the coordinates in a separate data frame for this to work. To do this we will use a mapping function. The mapping function applies a given function to each element of a vector and returns a vector of the same length. Our input vector will be the geometry column of us.bound. Our function will be st_centroid(). We will be using map_dbl variation of map from the purrr package.

To get our longitude values we map the st_centroid() function over the geometry column of us.bound and access the longitude value through double bracket notation [[]] and 1. This allows us to get only the longitude, which is the first value in each centroid.

longitude <- map_dbl(nga_wp$geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[1]])

We do the same for latitude with one key difference. We access the second value per each centroid with [[2]].

latitude <- map_dbl(nga_wp$geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[2]])

Now that we have latitude and longitude, we use cbind to put longitude and latitude into the same object.

coords <- cbind(longitude, latitude)

Determine the cut-off distance

Firstly, we need to determine the upper limit for distance band by using the steps below:

  • Return a matrix with the indices of points belonging to the set of the k nearest neighbours of each other by using knearneigh() of spdep.

  • Convert the knn object returned by knearneigh() into a neighbours list of class nb with a list of integer vectors containing neighbour region number ids by using knn2nb().

  • Return the length of neighbour relationship edges by using nbdists() of spdep. The function returns in the units of the coordinates if the coordinates are projected, in km otherwise.

  • Remove the list structure of the returned object by using unlist().

#coords <- coordinates(hunan)
k1 <- knn2nb(knearneigh(coords))
k1dists <- unlist(nbdists(k1, coords, longlat = TRUE))
summary(k1dists)

The summary report shows that the largest first nearest neighbour distance is 72km, using this as the upper threshold gives certainty that all units will have at least one neighbour.

Computing fixed distance weight matrix

Now, we will compute the distance weight matrix by using dnearneigh() as shown in the code chunk below.

wm_d72<- dnearneigh(coords, 0, 72,longlat = TRUE)
wm_d72

Next, nb2listw() is used to convert the nb object into spatial weights object.

wm72_lw <- nb2listw(wm_d72, style = 'B', zero.policy= TRUE)
summary(wm72_lw, zero.policy= TRUE)

Computing adaptive distance weight matrix

One of the characteristics of fixed distance weight matrix is that more densely settled areas (usually the urban areas) tend to have more neighbours and the less densely settled areas (usually the rural counties) tend to have lesser neighbours. Having many neighbours smoothes the neighbour relationship across more neighbours.

It is possible to control the numbers of neighbours directly using k-nearest neighbours, either accepting asymmetric neighbours or imposing symmetry as shown in the code chunk below.

knn <- knn2nb(knearneigh(coords, k=10))
knn

Next, nb2listw() is used to convert the nb object into spatial weights object.

knn_lw <- nb2listw(knn, style = 'B')
summary(knn_lw)

Computing Gi statistics

Gi statistics using fixed distance

fips <- order(nga_wp$ADM1_EN)
gi.fixed <- localG(nga_wp$`wpt non-functional`, wm72_lw)
gi.fixed

nga_wp.gi <- cbind(nga_wp, as.matrix(gi.fixed)) %>%
  rename(gstat_fixed = as.matrix.gi.fixed.)
wptinfo <- qtm(nga_wp, "wpt non-functional")

Gimap <-tm_shape(nga_wp.gi) +
  tm_fill(col = "gstat_fixed", 
          style = "pretty",
          palette="-RdBu",
          title = "local Gi") +
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)

tmap_arrange(wptinfo, Gimap, asp=1, ncol=2)

From the Gi Map, the southern regions have more clusters of non-functional water points and dispersed functional waterpoints. This area should be prioritized for repairs.

Gi statistics using adaptive distance

fips <- order(nga_wp$ADM1_EN)
gi.adaptive <- localG(nga_wp$`wpt non-functional`, knn_lw)
nga_wp.gi <- cbind(nga_wp, as.matrix(gi.adaptive)) %>%
  rename(gstat_adaptive = as.matrix.gi.adaptive.)

Mapping Gi values with adaptive distance weights

It is time for us to visualise the locations of hot spot and cold spot areas. The choropleth mapping functions of tmap package will be used to map the Gi values.

The code chunk below shows the functions used to map the Gi values derived using fixed distance weight matrix.

wptinfo<- qtm(nga_wp, "wpt non-functional")

Gimap <- tm_shape(nga_wp.gi) + 
  tm_fill(col = "gstat_adaptive", 
          style = "pretty", 
          palette="-RdBu", 
          title = "local Gi") + 
  tm_borders(alpha = 0.5)

tmap_arrange(wptinfo, 
             Gimap, 
             asp=1, 
             ncol=2)

Conclusion

Geospatial Autocorrelation is an important tool organisations can used to allocate limited resources to solve their issues. LISA and Gi can help organisations better understand geographical relationships with the analysis of certain attributes to support their decision-making processes.

Future Analysis

To deepen our understanding of the waterpoint distribution for decision-making on whether and where new waterpoints should be implemented, we can look at:

  • k-nearest neighbour: Including more samples for different neighbours and comparing the results would help increase confidence that the areas we picked out are indeed those of greatest concern for the lack of water access.

  • Population in the areas: This helps us understand the needs of the region based on the size of the populations inhabiting there. Number of functioning waterpoints per popoulation should be considered to better understand which regions have insufficient water sources and should be the focal areas for setting up new water points.
